claim: A video posted to TikTok and Instagram during the January 2024 polar vortex shows a woman in Canada making a helix out of ice by pouring it on the ground in a spiral pattern.
content:
Every few years, when the cold, arctic air of the polar vortex plunges south, internet users around the globe are treated to viral videos about the cold snap. Examples include frozen sculptures made of ramen and clothes as stiff as a board. You can even throw hot water into the air and watch it turn into a white cloud of steam and ice.
TikTok user QueenChelsea wanted to take it a step further in January 2024, posting a video to her TikTok and Instagram page showing her pouring water on the ground and creating a helix out of ice. The video quickly went viral, with over 13 million likes on TikTok (with 191 million views) and over 5 million likes on Instagram. The frozen sculpture looked real enough to fool many commenters, and Snopes received emails inquiring if the video was real.

Unfortunately, Canada being cold was the only real part of the video. Sorry to burst anyone's bubble (another great thing to play with in sub-zero temperatures), although it is certainly a testament to QueenChelsea's editing prowess that some people believed the ice sculpture was real.
QueenChelsea, whose real name is Chelsea Laufer, is a Canadian content creator who makes short viral videos using clever editing tricks and incredible visual effects. She included the VFX hashtag in the captions on both the TikTok and Instagram posts, and her bio on both platforms includes the sentence, "I like making impossible things."
Snopes reached out to Laufer for comment, and she replied via email.
"I’m a visual effects content creator so all of the videos I post are edited with a sort of magical realism in mind," she wrote. "I'll also add that the response to this video has been absolutely astounding! I made this video as a way to practice working with 3D CGI, and I never expected so many people to see it."
On Jan. 18, she posted a video to TikTok breaking down how she made the effect.

original_rationales.main_rationale: Canada being cold was the only real part of the video.

summary_rationales.synthesized_rationale: The claim has been rated as 'Fake' because the video of a woman creating a helix out of ice through pouring water on the ground during the January 2024 polar vortex was confirmed to be a visual effects creation by the TikTok and Instagram content creator, Chelsea Laufer. Despite the video going viral and appearing convincing to many viewers, it was ultimately a result of clever editing and visual effects, as clarified by Laufer herself.

detailed_reasons.reason1: The content creator, Chelsea Laufer, explicitly mentioned being a visual effects content creator and emphasized creating videos with 'magical realism.' This statement from Laufer indicates that the video in question was a product of editing and visual effects, aligning with the 'Fake' rating.
detailed_reasons.reason2: Snopes received inquiries about the authenticity of the video, showcasing that viewers were misled or unsure about its legitimacy. Laufer's acknowledgment of the astounding response to the video further reinforces the idea that many people believed the ice sculpture was real, highlighting the deceptive nature of the content.
detailed_reasons.reason3: Laufer's subsequent TikTok post breaking down how she produced the effect confirms that the video was a result of CGI manipulation rather than a genuine display of creating a helix out of ice with poured water. This breakdown serves as concrete evidence supporting the 'Fake' rating assigned to the claim.

evidence1: @queenchelsea Meanwhile in canada… ?? #vfx ♬ original sound - chelsea vfx
evidence2: @queenchelsea I accidentally tricked half the internet… ? #vfx #behindthescenes ♬ original sound - chelsea vfx

relationship_with_evidence.<main_rationale,evidence1>: Supportive. The evidence of a video showing a woman in Canada during the polar vortex aligns directly with the rationale detail that Canada being cold was the only authentic aspect of the content, reinforcing the claim's validity.

relationship_with_evidence.<reason1,evidence1>: Supportive. The evidence provided in the TikTok video clearly aligns with the rationale detail by indicating that Chelsea Laufer, known for her visual effects skills and focus on 'magical realism,' created the video using visual effects. This direct correlation strongly supports the 'Fake' rating assigned to the claim.

relationship_with_evidence.<reason3,evidence1>: Supportive. The evidence provided in the TikTok post by Laufer directly confirms that the video was a result of CGI manipulation rather than a genuine display of creating a helix out of ice with poured water, aligning perfectly with the rationale behind the 'Fake' rating assigned to the claim.

relationship_with_evidence.<reason1,evidence2>: Supportive. The evidence provided by Chelsea Laufer's statement about being a visual effects content creator and emphasizing creating videos with 'magical realism' directly aligns with the 'Fake' rating for the claim, suggesting that the video in question was indeed a product of editing and visual effects.

relationship_with_evidence.<reason3,evidence2>: Supportive. The evidence provided by @queenchelsea directly confirms Laufer's subsequent TikTok post, where Laufer breaks down how she produced the effect, revealing that the video was a result of CGI manipulation rather than a genuine display of creating a helix out of ice. This concrete evidence aligns perfectly with the rationale detailing the CGI manipulation involved, supporting the 'Fake' rating assigned to the claim.
